whenever they drill holes in the ice, i think afterwards they should cover the holes in a very reflective substance, like a thin layer of reflective foil.

whenever a tiny spot of the ice melts, that spot absorbs more of the sun's energy than the surrounding ice, causing a positive feedback loop, making that small melt area larger and larger. that's why icebreaker ships contribute so much to the ice melt in the polar regions. if you could cover the holes in a reflective foil that prevents those areas from heating up more than the surrounding ice, you could prevent the impact on the environment.

The salinity of the water around Antarctica is low due to melting ice. When the floating ice melts(Ice being 10% less dense than water, i.e. it occupies 10% more volume than liquid water) in the lower salinity water it actually causes the level of water to fall, so, as you pointed out recently, the incredibly difficult task of measuring sea levels would not notice any change at all. Shitty sound technicians is probably the biggest reason why people lose hearing.
The problem is too much square-shaped sound waves and music where volume is maximized throughout the song, which gives our ears no time to rest and recover - which ends up exhausting the muscles in our ear that exist to protect our receptors in our ears.
So my advice to people is to go away from a place when music is played so loud that it starts to feel painful in your ears.
Or at-least try to protect your ears with your hands. And don't try to be cool and not doing so only because everyone else doesn't, unless of course you want to have a premature hear loss.
